aws::graph::propositions: # Autopilot and Flight Control Examination Findings
The autopilot Nose UP and Nose DN buttons on the MFD operated correctly with associated elevator movement.
The autopilot Nose UP button on the MFD was used while the control wheel movement was restrained.
The restrained control wheel test verified the nose up electric auto pitch trim response.
The autopilot Nose DN button on the MFD was used while the control wheel movement was restrained.
The restrained control wheel test verified the nose down electric auto pitch trim response.
The examination of the airplane on August 21, 2014 revealed no evidence of an electrical fire.
The examination of the airplane on August 21, 2014 revealed no evidence of a short.
There was no burnt smell from the avionics equipment.
There was no burnt smell from the cockpit displays.
On September 24, 2012, a third examination of the flight controls and autopilot system was conducted.
The third examination was conducted by an avionics service facility with FAA oversight.
The autopilot preflight tests were conducted during the third examination.
No error messages were noted during the autopilot preflight tests.
Tests of the autopilot in the normal operating mode revealed no defects.
Operational tests of the autopilot in all modes were performed.
The roll mode of the autopilot followed heading commands.
The roll mode of the autopilot followed course changes.
The pitch mode of the autopilot functioned normally.
The auto trim functions of the autopilot functioned normally.
All disconnect functions of the autopilot operated normally.
The manual electric trim of the autopilot functioned normally.
The two integrated Garmin GIAs control the Garmin 700 autopilot system.
The two integrated Garmin GIAs were put into the maintenance mode.
The maintenance mode was accessed to view the maintenance logs.
The dates of all fault codes were prior to 2009.
None of the fault codes were related to servo issues.
None of the fault codes were related to the autopilot.
The static wicks on the ailerons were tested using a MEG OHM tester.
The static wicks on the elevator were tested using a MEG OHM tester.
The static wicks on the rudder were tested using a MEG OHM tester.
All static wicks were found to test between 6 to 15 MEG OHMS with 1,000 volts applied.
The static wicks test results were within allowable limits.
On January 31, 2013, the pitch servo was tested at another avionics facility.
On January 31, 2013, the pitch trim servo was tested at another avionics facility.
On January 31, 2013, the roll servo was tested at another avionics facility.
The servo tests were conducted with FAA oversight.
The servo tests were conducted to measure breakaway torque.

text:
# Autopilot and Flight Control Examination

## Autopilot Operation
1. The autopilot Nose UP and Nose DN buttons on the MFD operated correctly, with associated elevator movement.
2. The autopilot Nose UP button on the MFD was used, and the control wheel movement was restrained. This verified the nose up electric auto pitch trim response.
3. The autopilot Nose DN button on the MFD was used, and the control wheel movement was restrained. This verified the nose down electric auto pitch trim response.

## Electrical Examination
* The examination of the airplane on August 21, 2014, revealed no evidence of an electrical fire or a short.
* There was no burnt smell from the avionics equipment or cockpit displays.

## Autopilot System Examination
* On September 24, 2012, a third examination of the flight controls and autopilot system was conducted by an avionics service facility with FAA oversight.
* The autopilot preflight tests were conducted, and no error messages were noted.
* Tests of the autopilot in the normal operating mode revealed no defects.
* Operational tests of the autopilot in all modes were performed.
  * The roll mode followed heading commands and course changes.
  * The pitch mode functioned normally, including auto trim functions.
  * All disconnect functions operated normally, and the manual electric trim functioned normally.
* The two integrated Garmin GIAs that control the Garmin 700 autopilot system were put into the maintenance mode to access the maintenance logs.
* The dates of all fault codes were prior to 2009, and none of the fault codes were related to servo issues or the autopilot.

## Static Wicks Examination
* The static wicks on the ailerons, elevator, and rudder were tested using a MEG OHM tester.
* All static wicks were found to test between 6 to 15 MEG OHMS with 1,000 volts applied, which was within allowable limits.

## Servo Examinations
* On January 31, 2013, the pitch servo, the pitch trim servo, and the roll servo were tested at another avionics facility, with FAA oversight, to measure breakaway torque.
